text:
Hey–
I'm still relatively new to this channel, but have worked in MarComm in Higher Education for 17 years. I started as a graphic designer, but have been promoted multiple times in terms of responsibilities and skill sets. I'm finding "content marketing" means lots of things for lots of different positions at various companies. Wondering if anyone here comes from higher ed or can give some guidance on how to change industries or open up new opportunities. I do so much more than just design and am finding it difficult for companies to see that value.

text:
Hi there

I’m looking for connections to pursue a master’s.
I’m creating a podcast/Youtube channel called Not your typical questions with Hashem <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GvZW0MzWQLE4WIqc3g4TPZhlB9UNKor_fF6qi6CTXEY/edit?usp=sharing> where I ask people unusual questions.

I’m interested in doing a master’s to act as the theoretical bedrock of this podcast. The theory in the master’s will guide the practice and vice versa (e.g. If the books recommend asking hypothetical questions to unlock creativity then I can emphasize hypothetical questions in the podcast. Also, in order to  formulate my thesis, , I can analyze the episodes I created to see which questions created more insights. I’ll also be creating a blog with written articles to tackle relevant issues related to questions based on what internet users are interested in (SEO).

Relevant fields & Topics:
Psychology
Communication
Self-discovery
 Research Methodologies
 Conversation/Coaching
 Eureka/Scientific Discoveries
 Entertainment (Improv/comedy)
 Interdisciplinary
 Creativity


Here’s a document that I wrote earlier on the how and what of my research aspirations (Before I decided to focus on the podcast so not everything will be relevant)  <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZFqReSmE-Z7uzuxTRQXyg890favPimag/edit>  


Any thoughts/connections are appreciated!

Any thoughts/connections are appreciated!

text: Hi there! I've been working as a content marketing specialist in Chicago for the last several years and in 2019 was lucky enough to join a fantastic tech company with an incredibly influential, high traffic blog. Unfortunately, I really struggled with my mental health, imposter syndrome and focus, especially working from home during the pandemic. Even though I continued to churn out high-quality content I was really proud of and my manager was relatively supportive through those challenges, I ended being let go a couple months ago. Now that I'm on the job hunt again, I am struggling with how to approach conversations with potential employers about why I left my last role. :mild-panic: If anyone here has advice, essential readings, podcast episodes or anything else that might help me feel more confident going into interviews, I would really appreciate it!

elements.text: Hi there! I've been working as a content marketing specialist in Chicago for the last several years and in 2019 was lucky enough to join a fantastic tech company with an incredibly influential, high traffic blog. Unfortunately, I really struggled with my mental health, imposter syndrome and focus, especially working from home during the pandemic. Even though I continued to churn out high-quality content I was really proud of and my manager was relatively supportive through those challenges, I ended being let go a couple months ago. Now that I'm on the job hunt again, I am struggling with how to approach conversations with potential employers about why I left my last role.
If anyone here has advice, essential readings, podcast episodes or anything else that might help me feel more confident going into interviews, I would really appreciate it!

text:
Hey <@U02UR1WJE4E>, thanks for sharing your story so candidly. I think your perspective is one that many employers and people in general are sensitive to, because a ton of folks suffered with mental health during pandemic life.

It’s up to you whether you want to share that you were let go or if you moved on… but just make it more about your positive next steps forward. Like, “I’m looking for a role that will support balance in my life” or something like that.

Sounds like the transition wasn’t too long ago, so you may not need to explain yourself at all! Hope this was helpful.

elements.text: Hey

, thanks for sharing your story so candidly. I think your perspective is one that many employers and people in general are sensitive to, because a ton of folks suffered with mental health during pandemic life.

It’s up to you whether you want to share that you were let go or if you moved on… but just make it more about your positive next steps forward. Like, “I’m looking for a role that will support balance in my life” or something like that.

Sounds like the transition wasn’t too long ago, so you may not need to explain yourself at all! Hope this was helpful.

text: Hi - I have just come off a call earlier today with about 50 high level executives all in transition. It’s totally normal. i’m one of them. I feel much better having heard I’m not alone - and neither are you. The corporations do not determine your worth. You do.

elements.text: Hi - I have just come off a call earlier today with about 50 high level executives all in transition. It’s totally normal. i’m one of them. I feel much better having heard I’m not alone - and neither are you. The corporations do not determine your worth. You do.
Yes, love this so much.

text: Glad to know we’re all not alone. What was the best advice shared in these transitions?

elements.text: Glad to know we’re all not alone. What was the best advice shared in these transitions?

text: Very relatable situation, and I’m sorry you had to deal with that :heart: Like <@U02LGA1DB9N> said, in an interview setting I would focus on what *you* want from your next role/career step, rather than on your past company’s trajectory, relationship with your manager, etc. For general interview prep, I really like <https://www.themuse.com/advice/phone-interview-cheat-sheet|this article from The Muse> & the linked cheat sheet. I also found the book Brag Better by Meredith Fineman to be a helpful read!

attachments.fallback: The Muse: This Cheat Sheet Will Help You Ace Your Next Phone Interview
attachments.text: Make it clear you’re the right person for the job!
attachments.title: This Cheat Sheet Will Help You Ace Your Next Phone Interview

text: To combat imposter syndrome, I recommend making a list of all of your accomplishments & related metrics / antidotes — from this past role and others. Use those accomplishments to write your own narrative. Keep the list handy so you can keep adding to it and to read to yourself as a daily reminder of all you’ve accomplished. This has helped me sort through what I want (and don’t want) in my next role.

elements.text: To combat imposter syndrome, I recommend making a list of all of your accomplishments & related metrics / antidotes — from this past role and others. Use those accomplishments to write your own narrative. Keep the list handy so you can keep adding to it and to read to yourself as a daily reminder of all you’ve accomplished. This has helped me sort through what I want (and don’t want) in my next role.

text:
Hey <@U02UR1WJE4E>, thanks for sharing this—it can't have been easy. 

I would be very honest about what happened and call it what it was. (Why you were let go, what you learned, and why that company/role ultimately wasn't a fit for where you were then). Sounds like yes you were struggling, so own that part and what you'd do better. But it's also fair to say where the company let you down (so long as you don't make it sound really bad or like you're taking a dump in them—keep it clear but not overly negative). Find the balance in your answer, and you should be ok. Recruiter s and hiring managers get that sometimes things just aren't a fit. 

Another reason I recommend honesty? Whenever I interview someone who's honest about being let go, I do not judge at all and really appreciate and admire their honesty. I had a candidate be a bit murky about it, and I found out (cause it's a small world and I knew the team they'd worked on), and after I found out, I was worried about how open and honest they'd be with me as a manager, and took a pass at that time on them. :(

Just some food for thought. You want to be on a team that (ideally) accepts you for who you are. Tons of high performing people have been let go of from jobs for a multitude of reason. (I probably will be someday, cause high growth tech can be tough.) There's no shame in it—so I say be as honest as possible. You don't want to work for someone who would hold it against you. :heart:

, thanks for sharing this—it can't have been easy. 

I would be very honest about what happened and call it what it was. (Why you were let go, what you learned, and why that company/role ultimately wasn't a fit for where you were then). Sounds like yes you were struggling, so own that part and what you'd do better. But it's also fair to say where the company let you down (so long as you don't make it sound really bad or like you're taking a dump in them—keep it clear but not overly negative). Find the balance in your answer, and you should be ok. Recruiter s and hiring managers get that sometimes things just aren't a fit. 

Another reason I recommend honesty? Whenever I interview someone who's honest about being let go, I do not judge at all and really appreciate and admire their honesty. I had a candidate be a bit murky about it, and I found out (cause it's a small world and I knew the team they'd worked on), and after I found out, I was worried about how open and honest they'd be with me as a manager, and took a pass at that time on them. :(

Just some food for thought. You want to be on a team that (ideally) accepts you for who you are. Tons of high performing people have been let go of from jobs for a multitude of reason. (I probably will be someday, cause high growth tech can be tough.) There's no shame in it—so I say be as honest as possible. You don't want to work for someone who would hold it against you.

text:
I was in a similar situation at my last job, mostly due to the work environment — but I quit instead. Still, I was very nervous that I didn't have a lot of results or things to show from that job, and I was soooo concerned nobody would ever want to hire me again. In fact, that fear kept me in the toxic job a whole year longer than I should've been. I don't regret anything, but I look back at how misguided that fear was and I wish I could tell past me to trust myself to figure it out. Would've saved a lot of sleepless nights.

Fast forward, I literally got recruited, shortly after leaving, to a better job with better pay, better benefits, better opportunities, and none of the toxicity of the last gig. Here are some things I think helped:

• I reached out to my network when I left the role and was top of mind for <@UJ7RT1J1X> to recommend me to my current gig when the hiring manager asked him for potential candidates (thanks again!!) It's hard to ask for help but people want to help you, I've seen it again and again!
• When discussing my past job and why we parted ways, I was honest without throwing them under the bus. I basically said I was grateful for what I learned there but that it was no longer a good match and that had created friction that was really affecting my mental health, so I left to recharge. All four people who interviewed me asked, and none of them dug any deeper after I gave that basic response. I think we over-anticipate how judgmental hiring managers will be but they're human too and they understand this happens. We have all burned out before. (And if they don't understand, that's a :triangular_flag_on_post:)
• Because I knew I didn't have a lot of results at my last role, I did a TON of research on the new role and came to each interview armed with my general diagnosis for the content operation’s wins and losses, along with a few specific things I would do to fix them. Hiring manager loved this, I even bought a month of Ahrefs to analyze their top performing pages. We spent 80% of the interviews discussing these ideas and my content philosophy. It makes sense if you think about it, he cared about the problems he had to solve more than the problems I solved for other people in the past. 
• This approach necessarily prioritizes quality over quantity in the job search, but I personally would take that approach no matter what. Blasting resumes into the void seems to still be the advice a lot of people still give, but that's in opposition to everything that has worked for me in the past
• I knew I would eventually have to talk about my past performance, so I dug deep to find my three top performing projects at my last job and analyzed them from every angle I could to figure out how I could position them in the most favorable light. In my experience, you need a project that generated tangible results, a project that was challenging but ultimately successful and a project you worked on with others at minimum to cover the kinds of “past experience” questions that get asked. Also use the <https://www.themuse.com/amp/advice/star-interview-method|STAR method> to handle these types of questions to present them in the best light. Again, the key is spending most of the time on what you would do at the new role and using these examples to reinforce that (or to answer if directly asked about past projects)
• I had what a mentor once called an “art gallery” which is basically what <@U024QUK2AVD> mentioned. It's a huge help for imposter syndrome and interview prep, and it's never too late to make one.
DM me if you want to chat further with someone who gets it :blush: I'm happy to be a resource in your job hunt and take a look at your samples or offer more specific advice on the roles you're applying to. Might even be able to connect you with some other folks I know.

attachments.fallback: The Muse: How to Use the STAR Interview Method to Get the Job
attachments.text: Don’t panic when you hear, “Tell me about a time when…” Just use STAR. It’s simple.
attachments.title: How to Use the STAR Interview Method to Get the Job

text:
Hey all, I recently became aware of an interesting clause in our company handbook. The wording is super vague but it essentially says employees can't be solicited without management approval. (How that's enforceable I don't know since it doesn't say anything about *responding* to said solicitations.)

This strikes me as:

1. Out of touch with reality. How reasonable is it to expect recruiters won't come knocking for high performers? Or that career opportunities won't be shared and talked about on LinkedIn and in communities like this? 
2. A subtly roundabout way to keep people from leaving.
To be clear, it's not a non-compete clause or NDA-type situation. Idk, just feels...weird. Am I overreacting? Have you run into this before?

Would love any insights and advice you have :pray:

Would love any insights and advice you have

text: wow there is so much good advice in this thread. <@U02UR1WJE4E> i talk to hiring managers all the time and they are so eager to find good people. most are incredibly kind and thoughtful people to boot. if you see any roles on the job that you're interested in, pls shoot me a DM and let me know. i'll be happy to help out however i can (reviewing writing samples/cover letter, chatting about the role or just cheer you on!)
